awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of advanced memory devices.  The memory sector is expected to take ~27% (~175 billion USD) of the total semiconductor market (~650 billion USD) by 2025 and plays a crucial role in computer systems, electronic gadgets, data centers, and cloud service systems.  Currently, NAND flash technology, the dominant storage technology, has several disadvantages such as device scaling, limited endurance, low operational writing speed and requires a high write voltage and high-power consumption.  The proposed technology is a resistive random-access memory (RRAM)-based non-volatile memory (NVM) technology that offers competitive solutions to the challenges of  current memory technology due to its simple structure, the possibility of excellent scalability, which allows for the storage of more data, nanosecond operation speed, which allows for faster access and processing of data, and nanowatts power consumption, which increases the battery life of devices and reduces costs.  The proposed RRAM may be used in a variety of Internet of Things (IoT) devices to enable faster data processing and longer battery life. In addition, the automotive industry may adopt this technology for advanced driver assistance systems and autonomous driving systems to provide high performance storage. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of ultralow power (10 – 200 nW) resistive random-access memory (RRAM) devices. The proposed RRAM devices including the electrodes, carrier transport, interface properties between the contacts, and resistive switching layers of the have been systematically studied.  The devices exhibit ultra-low power operation under a 10 nA operating current with excellent resistive switching characteristics, such as highly uniform I-V characteristics with concentrated SET and RESET voltages, and excellent stability.  In addition, these proposed RRAM devices have multi-bit storage capability with a high Roff/Ron ratio (>103). The multi-bit resistive switching behaviors of the RRAM devices at a low compliance current pave the way for low-power and high-density data storage applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Team 3205, Low Power Memory Chips, led by Mano Bala Sankar Muthu as the Entrepreneur Lead, with Carly Heissenbuttel as the Industrial Mentor and Hieu P. T. Nguyen as the Technical Lead, successfully completed the National Science Foundation (NSF) I-Corps program as part of the National Fall 2023 Cohort. Over the course of the program, the team conducted over 116 customer discovery interviews, gaining critical insights to guide the development and commercialization of their innovative low-power memory chip technology.

In an era of increasing data demands and energy constraints, the development of low-power memory chips has emerged as a critical priority for the semiconductor industry. RRAM has positioned itself as a promising candidate for addressing these challenges.

This program helped us to validate our value propositions and develop an efficient business model canvas. We have learnt several important suggestions from the customer discovery. Before starting this project, we have had several value propositions, however, those were not clearly defined and quantified. Joining this I-corps program, we received important feedback which definitely helped us improve our business model canvas. We could be able to identify our most potential customer segment as Cloud Storage Companies and Memory Manufacturing Companies to scale down their memories without performance degradation, reduce complexity and power consumption. 

Through 116 structured customer discovery interactions, the project unearthed key insights that shaped the RRAM development process. The customer base included semiconductor companies, material device manufacturers, automotive electronics providers, and cloud service providers. The following outcomes emerged:

  • Energy Efficiency as a Top Priority
  • Performance Metrics Validation
  • Scalability and Cost Concerns
  • Emerging Applications and Ecosystem Needs (Software and Tools)
  • Technical and Commercial Outcomes

Based on the insights gained from the project and customer discovery process, a business centered on RRAM technology presents a compelling opportunity for growth and innovation. Using the Business Model Canvas framework, the next target key customer segments such as Memory device manufacturers, automotive electronics companies, space systems and AI/ML hardware providers. Key revenue streams would include direct sales of memory chips, licensing proprietary RRAM designs, and providing customized memory solutions. To achieve this, we are focusing on key activities such as advancing RRAM technology with multiple lab trials, forging partnerships with semiconductor foundries (Intel, Micron, Global Foundries), and building a robust software ecosystem to ease integration. Our immediate plans are to improve the device performance/product development and seek supports from NSF SBIR/STTR, and PFI grants.    


Last Modified: 01/13/2025
Modified by: Hieu P Nguyen
